    {
      "title": "Use pasta water for consistency",
      "description": "The video explains using reserved pasta water to adjust the consistency of the sauce if it becomes too thick.",

        "type": "text",

        "text": "Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water."

      "reasoning": "This technique helps to prevent the eggs from scrambling when mixed with the hot pasta.",
      "comparison": "The previous video does not mention this technique of adding pasta water to the egg mixture before combining it with the pasta.",
      "quotes": [
        "Another thing you can do is just take a little bit of that boiling water and add it to the eggs. Quickly whisk that in."
      ],
      "other_quotes": [
        "Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting."
      ],
      "classification": "instructions"
    }
  ],
  "contradictory_information": [

      "title": "No cream or peas needed",

        "type": "text",
        "text": "Turn this pan on to medium heat."

        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan, and what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water."
      },

        "type": "text",
        "text": "So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese."

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It's so simple!"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Let's not waste any time, now let's go!"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And thickcut bacon would be best."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You could also use pancetta."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That's about three quarters of an inch."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Turn this pan on to medium heat."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan, and what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So here's all our beautiful cheese."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Okay, now time for the eggs."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I like to do a mixture of both."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks."

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It's so simple!"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",

        "type": "text",

      },

        "text": "## Current Video:`\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It's so simple!"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Let's not waste any time, now let's go!"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And thickcut bacon would be best."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You could also use pancetta."

        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way."
      },

        "type": "text",
        "text": "That's about three quarters of an inch."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Turn this pan on to medium heat."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan, and what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So here's all our beautiful cheese."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",

        "type": "text",

        "type": "text",

      "reasoning": "This technique helps control the heat and prevent the eggs from scrambling, ensuring a creamy sauce.",
      "comparison": "The previous video does not mention using a bain-marie technique for heating the egg mixture.",
      "quotes": [
        "literally what you can do is set that pan back on top of that pasta water and like a double boil or bainmarie, it will keep cooking the egg mixture."
      ],
      "other_quotes": [],

  "supplementary_information": [

      "comparison": "The previous video does not mention this technique for preparing pepper.",
      "quotes": [
        "Get your peppercorns in a pestle and mortar. Crack it. Get a little sieve. This is one of the most important little bits and no one really does it, okay. Honestly, this is the outer skin. This is much milder. What we have here is the inside part, the peppercorn, which is hotter."
      ],
      "other_quotes": [
        "Abundant pepper."
      ],

      "title": "Emulsifying with Pasta Water",

  "supplementary_information": [
    {
      "title": "Time Sensitivity with Eggs",
      "description": "The video emphasizes the importance of being time-sensitive when adding eggs to prevent them from scrambling.",
      "reasoning": "Timing is crucial to ensure the eggs create a creamy sauce rather than scrambling due to excessive heat.",
      "comparison": "The previous video mentions not scrambling the eggs but does not emphasize the time sensitivity as much.",
      "quotes": [
        "Now, we're time sensitive so we're gonna have a little whisk up.",
        "Eggs are really, really delicate and if you don't treat these right, you end up with stirfried noodles and we don't want that."
      ],
      "other_quotes": [
        "You see usually by this stage the heat is so much in the wrong cooking that the eggs become scrambled eggs. Not too scrambly."
      ],
      "classification": "instructions"
    },

      "title": "Finishing with Pecorino and Pepper",

thickness.\",\"quotes\":[\"In this case, it's sort of spaghettoni, the biggest size of spaghetti.\"],\"other_quotes\":[\"Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.\"],\"classification\":\"materials\"},{\"title\":\"Guanciale preferred over pancetta\",\"description\":\"The current video emphasizes using guanciale over pancetta for authenticity.\",\"reasoning\":\"Guanciale is considered more traditional and flavorful for Carbonara.\",\"comparison\":\"The previous video uses bacon or pancetta, noting         "type": "text",

        "type": "text",
        "text": "Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured."
      },
      {

        "text": "So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And thickcut bacon would be best."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You could also use pancetta."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That's about three quarters of an inch."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Turn this pan on to medium heat."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan, and what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese."
      },

      "description": "Do not add oil to the pasta water when cooking pasta for Carbonara.",

        "While this is cooking, it takes good 10 minutes, and no oil, please. No oil, because you don't need it."
      ],
      "other_quotes": [],
      "classification": "instructions"
    },
    {
      "title": "Cooling pasta before adding eggs",
      "description": "Let the pasta cool slightly before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling.",
      "reasoning": "Cooling the pasta slightly helps to prevent the eggs from cooking too quickly and turning into scrambled eggs.",
      "comparison": "The previous video does not explicitly mention cooling the pasta before adding the eggs, focusing instead on turning off the heat.",

        "You let it cool down in doing this. And it shouldn't be too hot because what is going to happen now should be the temperature enough to coat the egg around the pasta."
